q: What are the symptoms of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: Symptoms of NMO can include eye pain, loss of vision, weakness in the arms and legs, painful muscle spasms, and bladder, bowel, and sexual problems.

q: How is Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) diagnosed?
a: NMO is diagnosed through further testing by a neurologist, including MRI scans of the brain and spinal cord, blood tests, and possibly a lumbar puncture.

q: What treatments are available for Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: There is no cure for NMO, but treatments such as steroids, immune suppressants, and rehabilitation techniques can help ease symptoms and prevent relapses.

q: What causes Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: NMO is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks healthy tissues, although it is usually not inherited.

q: When should I seek medical help for symptoms of NMO?
a: If you experience any symptoms of NMO, it is recommended to see a GP who can refer you to a neurologist for further testing and diagnosis.

q: Can Optic neuritis affect my ability to drive?
a: Yes, Optic neuritis, a symptom of NMO, may affect your ability to drive. You should inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) about any medical condition that could affect your driving.

q: What support is available for people with Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: There are support groups and charities such as The Brain & Spine Foundation, The Brain Charity, Transverse Myelitis Society, and The Walton Centre that can provide support and resources for people with NMO.

q: Can Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) be registered with the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: Yes, individuals with NMO can have their information passed on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) to contribute to research on better prevention and treatment methods.

q: What is the gender distribution of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: NMO is more common in women than men.

q: What can trigger relapses in Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)?
a: The triggers for relapses in NMO are not fully understood and can be unpredictable.

q: What are some symptoms of NMO?
a: Some symptoms of NMO include eye pain, loss of vision, weakness in the arms and legs, pain in the arms or legs, increased sensitivity to cold and heat, and bladder, bowel, and sexual problems.

q: What is transverse myelitis?
a: Transverse myelitis is when the spinal cord becomes swollen and irritated in people with NMO.

q: How can NMO be diagnosed?
a: NMO can be diagnosed through further testing done by a neurologist, such as MRI scans, blood tests, and lumbar puncture.

q: What are the treatments for NMO?
a: There is no cure for NMO, but treatments can help ease symptoms and prevent future relapses. These may include steroids, immune system suppressants, rituximab, and rehabilitation techniques like physiotherapy.

q: What causes NMO?
a: NMO is an autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks healthy tissues. It is usually not inherited, but people with NMO may have a history of autoimmune disorders in their family.

q: How does optic neuritis affect driving?
a: Optic neuritis, a symptom of NMO, may affect one's ability to drive. It is important to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) about any medical conditions that could impact driving.

q: Where can I find support for NMO?
a: Support for NMO is available through organizations like The Brain & Spine Foundation, The Brain Charity, Transverse Myelitis Society, and national research centers like The Walton Centre and John Radcliffe Hospital.

q: What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)?
a: The NCARDRS is a service where clinical teams can pass information about individuals with NMO to aid in research and finding better ways to prevent and treat the condition.

q: What are the symptoms of NMO?
a: Symptoms of NMO may include eye pain, loss of vision, faded colors, weakness in the arms and legs, pain in the arms or legs, increased sensitivity to cold and heat, muscle spasms, vomiting, and bladder, bowel, and sexual problems.

q: What should I do if I have symptoms of NMO?
a: If you have symptoms of NMO, you should see a GP who will refer you to a neurologist for further testing and diagnosis.

q: How is NMO diagnosed?
a: NMO is diagnosed through further testing such as MRI scans, blood tests, and lumbar puncture to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.

q: What are the treatments for NMO?
a: While there is no cure for NMO, treatments can help ease symptoms, prevent relapses, and slow down the progression of the condition. Treatments may include steroids to reduce inflammation, immune-suppressing medications, and rehabilitation techniques like physiotherapy.

q: What causes NMO?
a: NMO is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks healthy tissues. It is usually not inherited, but some individuals with NMO may have a family history of autoimmune disorders.

q: Can I drive if I have NMO?
a: Optic neuritis, a symptom of NMO, may affect your ability to drive. You have a legal obligation to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) about any medical condition that could impact your driving.

q: Where can I find support for NMO?
a: There are various sources of support available for individuals with NMO, such as connecting with charities like The Brain & Spine Foundation, The Brain Charity, and the Transverse Myelitis Society.

q: How can I contribute to NMO research?
a: If you have NMO, your clinical team can share information about you with the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) to help scientists find better ways to prevent and treat NMO.

q: What is the role of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)?
a: The NCARDRS helps scientists in the UK seek advancements in preventing and treating NMO by collecting information from individuals with NMO and rare diseases. Participation in the register is voluntary.
